case_name: Civil Appeal No. 2356 of 1968 and connected appeals

facts.text: U.P. Regulation of Building Operations Act 1958 received the assent of the President on October 8, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The U.P.  Regulation of Building Operations  Act 1958 received the assent of the President on October 8, 1958. On December 10, 1958 a numberification was issued by the U.P. Government declaring Ghaziabad a regulated area under S. 3 of the aforesaid Act.

facts.text: On December 10, 1958 a notification was issued by the U.P. Government declaring Ghaziabad a regulated area under S. 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On December 10, 1958 a numberification was issued by the U.P. Government declaring Ghaziabad a regulated area under S. 3 of the aforesaid Act. In February 1959 the Controlling Authority under S. 4 of the Regulation Act was companystituted.

facts.text: In February 1959 the Controlling Authority under S. 4 of the Regulation Act was constituted.

anchor.surface_text: In February 1959 the Controlling Authority under S. 4 of the Regulation Act was companystituted. On July 16, 1960 a numberification was issued under S. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act by the State Government declaring its intention to acquire land measuring about 34,000 acres in fifty villages of Ghaziabad for planned development of the area.

facts.text: On July 16, 1960 a notification was issued under S. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act declaring intention to acquire about 34,000 acres in fifty villages of Ghaziabad for planned development.

anchor.surface_text: On July 16, 1960 a numberification was issued under S. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act by the State Government declaring its intention to acquire land measuring about 34,000 acres in fifty villages of Ghaziabad for planned development of the area.

facts.text: On December 23, 1961 a notification was issued under ss. 6 and 17 of the Acquisition Act in respect of an area of 19.75 acres.

anchor.surface_text: On December 23, 1961 a numberification was issued under ss. 6 and 17 of the Acquisition Act in respect of an area of 19.75 acres. This was followed by successive piecemeal numberifications on various dates in 1962 and 1963.

facts.text: On February 9, 1962 a notification was issued under S. 4 modifying the earlier notification dated July 16, 1960, reducing the proposed area from 34,000 acres to 6158 acres.

anchor.surface_text: On Feb- ruary 9, 1962 another numberification was issued under S. 4 of the Acquisition Act modifying the earlier numberification dated July 16, 1960. By this numberification the proposed area from 34,000 acres was reduced to 6158 acres.

facts.text: On July 4, 1962 the appellants made an application to the Special Land Acquisition Officer Ghaziabad for a copy of the scheme of planned development.

anchor.surface_text: On July 4, 1962 the appellants made an application to the Special Land Acquisition Officer Ghaziabad for supplying a companyy of the scheme of the planned development for which numberification under S. 4 had been issued to enable them to make representations at the hearing of the objections filed under S. 5A of the Acquisition Act.

facts.text: Special Land Acquisition Officer ordered that the scheme of planned development is not necessary for notification under S. 4 and no such scheme is available.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Land Acquisition Officer made the following order on that application The scheme of the planned development is number necessary for a numberification under S. 4 of the Act, as such, numbersuch scheme of the planned development is available in this office.

facts.text: On September 4, 1962 the State Government sanctioned the Master Plan of Ghaziabad under the Regulation Act.

anchor.surface_text: On September, 4, 1962 the State Government sanctioned the Master Plan of Ghaziabad under the Regulation Act. On Sept- ember 27, 1962 a writ petition was filed by the appellants in the High Court challenging the validity of the aforesaid numberifications.

facts.text: On September 27, 1962 a writ petition was filed by the appellants in the High Court challenging the validity of the notifications.

anchor.surface_text: On Sept- ember 27, 1962 a writ petition was filed by the appellants in the High Court challenging the validity of the aforesaid numberifications. Several other writ petitions were also filed by other petitioners.

facts.text: On December 10, 1965 a batch of 39 writ petitions including the appellants' were allowed by the High Court quashing notifications under s.6 due to invalid piecemeal notifications.

anchor.surface_text: On December 10, 1965 a batch of 39 writ petitions including the appellants petition were allowed by the, High Court and the numberifications under s. 6 of the Acquisitions Act were quashed on the ground of invalidity of piecemeal numberifications.

facts.text: On February 9, 1966 Supreme Court decided in State of Madhya Pradesh v. Vishnu Prasad Sharma that piecemeal notifications under s.6 are not permissible.

anchor.surface_text: On February 9, 1966 this companyrt decided in State of Madhya Pradesh Others v. Vishnu Prasad Sharma Others 1  that piecemeal and Successive numberifications under s. 6 of the Acquisition Act was number permissible.

facts.text: On February 20, 1967 the President promulgated Land Acquisition Amendment Validation Ordinance No. 1 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: On February 20, 1967 the President of India promulgated the Land Acquisition  Amendment Validation  Ordinance No. 1 of 1967.

facts.text: In April 1967 an Act was passed on the same lines as the Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: In April 1967 an Act was passed on the same lines as the Ordinance. The provisions of the Act were also challenged before the High Court by necessary amendment in the writ petitions filed by the appellants.

facts.text: On March 26, 1968 the Allahabad High Court dismissed the writ petition of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: On March 26, 1968 the High Court dismissed the writ petition of the appellants. In view of the judgment of this Court the High Court repelled the companytentions of the appellants impugning the validity of the Acquisition Amendment Act 1967.

facts.text: Notification under s.4 dated July 16, 1960 stated land likely needed for public purpose: planned development of the area.

anchor.surface_text: Reference has been made to the numberification dated July 14 1960 issued under s. 4 as also to subsequent numberification dated February 9, 1962 amending the earlier numberification. The earlier numberification to the extent it is material is as follows - In pursuance of the provisions of under  ?  sub-s.  1  of section 4 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894  Act No. 1 of 1894 , the Governor of U.P. is pleased  1  1966 3 S.C.R. 557.

facts.text: Appellants claimed in writ petition that notification under s.4 was vague, no indication of specific purposes or scheme.

anchor.surface_text: In the writ petition a specific plea was taken in paras 3 5  b  and 36 that numberproper, reasonable or effective opportunity was available to the appellants to file any objections under s. 5A of the Acquisition Act inasmuch as the numberification gave numberindication that different pieces of land would be acquired for different authorities in different circumstances and for different purposes.

facts.text: In counter-affidavit para 9, respondent denied para 33 of petition, stated scheme for planned development existed when s.4 issued, though not finalized in details.

anchor.surface_text: In the return which was filed Para 9 companytained the reply to Para 33 and this is what was stated That the allegations made in paragraph 33 of the petition are denied. The scheme for the planned development of the area was there when the numberification under section 4 of the Land Acquisition Act was issued although the scheme at that stage had number been finalised in the details.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that vagueness of public purpose in s.4 notification prevented effective objections under s.5A.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that owing to the vagueness and indefiniteness of the public purpose stated in the numberifications under s. 4 1  and in the absence of any proof that the appellants were either aware of or were shown the scheme or the Master Plan in respect of the planned development of the area in question the appellants were wholly unable to object effectively and exercise their right under s. 5A of the Acquisition Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeals and quashed the entire acquisition proceedings in respect of the lands of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above these appeals must succeed and are hereby allowed. The entire acquisition proceedings in respect of the lands of the appellants in all the appeals are, hereby quashed.

facts.text: Appeals are from judgments of Allahabad High Court dated March 26, 1968 and April 2, 1968 by certificate under Article 133.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals No. 2356 of 1968. Appeal by certificate under Article 133 of the Constitution of India from the judgment and order dated March 26, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Writ No. 662 of 1971 and Civil Appeals Nos. 1139, 1475 and 1476 of 1971.

facts.text: This Court in Udai Ram Sharma v. Union of India upheld the validity of the Land Acquisition Amending Act of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Udai Ram Sharma A Othrs etc. v. Union of India Others 2  upheld the validity of the Acquisition Amending Act of 1967.

Appeal by certificate under Article 133 of the Constitution of India from the judgment and order dated March 26, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Writ No. 662 of 1971 and Civil Appeals Nos. 1139, 1475 and 1476 of 1971.

holdings.text: owing to the vagueness and indefiniteness of the public purpose stated in the notifications under s. 4(1) and in the absence of any proof that the appellants were either aware of or were shown the scheme or the Master Plan in respect of the planned development of the area in question the appellants were wholly unable to object effectively and exercise their right under s. 5A of the Acquisition Act.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that owing to the vagueness and indefiniteness of the public purpose stated in the numberifications under s. 4 1  and in the absence of any proof that the appellants were either aware of or were shown the scheme or the Master Plan in respect of the planned development of the area in question the appellants were wholly unable to object effectively and exercise their right under s. 5A of the Acquisition Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public purpose in s.4(1) must enable effective s.5A objections; 'planned development of the area' too vague without particulars or proof of knowledge of scheme; distinguished precedents like Arnold Rodricks and Babu Barkya Thakur.

holdings.text: the mere words, as are to be found in the notifications here planned development of the area were wholly insufficient and conveyed no idea as to the specific purpose for which the lands were to be utilised.

anchor.surface_text: But tile mere words, as are to be found in the numberifications here planned development of the area were wholly insufficient and companyveyed numberidea as to the specific purpose for which the lands were to be utilised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4(1) requires sufficient particularity in public purpose for s.5A; mere 'planned development' inadequate as it could encompass various uses without specifics.

holdings.text: This Court in Udai Ram Sharma A Othrs etc. v. Union of India Others upheld the validity of the Acquisition Amending Act of 1967.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent upholding validity of 1967 Amendment Act validating piecemeal notifications.

precedents.case_name: Nandeshwar Prasad v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: the right to file objections under s. 5A is a substantial right when a person's property is being threatened with acquisition and that right cannot be taken away as if by a side wind

precedents.case_name: Arnold Rodricks v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: public purpose specified as development and utilisation of the lands as an industrial and residential area was sufficient
precedents.cited_holding: the purpose specified was a public purpose within the Acquisition Act

precedents.citation: Babu Barkya Thakur v. The State of Bombay Others 1 1961 1 S.C.R. 128

anchor.surface_text: In Babu Barkya Thakur v. The State of Bombay Others 1  it was stated in the numberification under S. 4 1  that the land was likely to be needed for purposes of a. companypany which was named. A challenge was made against the validity of that

precedents.case_name: Babu Barkya Thakur v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: where land required for company, notification under s.4 need not state public purpose if satisfied under s.5A or s.40; purpose of s.4 notification is preliminary investigation
precedents.cited_holding: any defect in the notification under s.4 is not fatal particularly for company acquisition

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above these appeals must succeed and are hereby allowed. The entire acquisition proceedings in respect of the lands of the appellants in all the appeals are, hereby quashed. In matters of this nature we would have taken due numberice of laches on the part of the appellants while granting the above relief but we are satisfied that so far as the present appellants are companycerned they have number been guilty of laches, delay or acquiescence at any stage.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that owing to the vagueness and indefiniteness of the public purpose stated in the numberifications under s. 4 1  and in the absence of any proof that the appellants were either aware of or were shown the scheme or the Master Plan in respect of the planned development of the area in question the appellants were wholly unable to object effectively and exercise their right under s. 5A of the Acquisition Act.
